item.title: How to Increase Health, Armor, and Ammo in DOOM The Dark Ages (& All Upgrade Locations)
item.description:
When players begin their DOOM: The Dark Ages playthrough, they'll find that their health and armor are limited to just 100 and 50, respectively. During the opening stages and when playing the game on lower difficulty settings, this shouldn't be too much of an issue. However, on higher difficulty settings where the amount of damage that players take is increased, having such limited defenses will likely prove problematic.

Thankfully, it's possible to upgrade the Slayer's health and armor capacity to 200 and 150, which can make survival a whole lot easier. Players can also increase their maximum ammo capacity, and will receive several Trophies/Achievements for maxing out all three. This guide will explain how to upgrade ammo, armor, and health in DOOM: The Dark Ages , as well as the chapters in which each of the upgrades can be found.

How to Increase Max Health, Armor, and Ammo in DOOM: The Dark Ages

To upgrade the Slayer's health, armor, and ammo, players will need to find Demonic Essences , which are acquired by beating special demon variants known as Leaders. The vast majority of Leaders are unmissable, although there are a handful that are tied to optional objectives, so players hoping to fully upgrade everything should keep their eyes peeled for Gore Nests as they make their way through the main story. Each Demonic Essence will increase the player's health or armor by ten.

Most of the optional Gore Nests are dotted along the critical path, although there are a couple in Chapters where the Slayer uses his dragon that can be easily missed if players don't fully explore the area. Usually, though, there'll be challenges that alert them to optional encounters and hidden landing zones.

All Health Upgrades in DOOM: The Dark Ages

There are ten Demonic Essences that increase the Slayer's health, which can be found in chapters 2, 5, 7, 9, 10, 12, 14, 15, 19, and 20. Finding all of them will unlock the Essential Health Trophy / Achievement.

All Armor Upgrades in DOOM: The Dark Ages

As with health, there are ten Demonic Essences that increase armor capacity. Players can find them in chapters 4, 6, 8, 10, 11, 13, 15, 16, 18, and 20, and will earn the Essential Armor Trophy / Achievement for getting them all.

All Ammo Upgrades in DOOM: The Dark Ages

There are twelve Demonic Essences tied to ammo, with each of the four main ammo types getting three a piece. They can be found in chapters 5, 6, 9, 10, 13, 14, 16, 17 (x2), 19, 20, and 22, and finding them all will reward players with the Essential Ammo Trophy / Achievement.

If players acquire all of the Demonic Essence upgrades in DOOM: The Dark Ages , they'll be rewarded with the Essentially Unstoppable Trophy / Achievement.

item.title: All DOOM The Dark Ages Weapons (& When You Unlock Them)
item.description:
The DOOM franchise is well-known for its awe-inspiring arsenal of demon-destroying weapons, and DOOM: The Dark Ages continues with this rich tradition. When they first start playing the game, players will only have access to the Slayer's iconic Combat Shotgun, but as they progress, they'll be able to get their hands on a wide array of exciting weapons.

There are 15 DOOM: The Dark Ages weapons in total, plus the Slayer's Shield Saw and four special runes that players can use with it. None of these items are missable, and all but one of them can be upgraded by visiting a Sentinel Shrine. Most upgrade paths are fairly linear, although some weapons allow players to choose between two different skills/abilities.

All Equipment Unlocks in DOOM: The Dark Ages

  • Chapter 1 (Village of Khalim) - Power Gauntlet + Shredder
  • Chapter 2 (Hebeth) - Shield Saw + Accelerator
  • Chapter 4 (Sentinel Barracks) - Pulverizer + Impaler
  • Chapter 5 (The Holy City of Aratum) - Cycler + Super Shotgun
  • Chapter 6 (Siege - Part 1) - Flail + Chainshot
  • Chapter 8 (Abyssal Forest) - Grenade Launcher
  • Chapter 9 (Ancestral Forge) - Ground Fissure Shield Rune
  • Chapter 10 (The Forsaken Plains) - Rocket Launcher
  • Chapter 11 (Hellbreaker) - Holy Swarm Shield Rune
  • Chapter 12 (Sentinel Command Station) - Ravager + Auto Turret Shield Rune
  • Chapter 14 (Spire of Nerathul) - Heaven Splitter Shield Rune + Ballistic Force Crossbow
  • Chapter 15 (City of Ry'uul) - Dreadmace

Combat Shotgun

All Combat Shotgun Upgrades

  • Incendiary (Tier 1) - Dealing enough damage to a demon with the Combat Shotgun applies Burn. Demons affected by burn drop armor pickups.
  • Smelt (Tier 2) - Demons affected by Burn applied by the Combat Shotgun drop more armor pickups.
  • Blast (Tier 2) - Burn applied by the Combat Shotgun causes demons to explode on death.
  • Tune Up (Tier 3) - The Combat Shotgun fires in rapid, three-round bursts.
  • Flare-Up (Tier 3) - The Combat Shotgun instantly applies Burn to fodder demons.
  • Eat This! (Tier 4) - The Combat hotgun fires an increased number of projectiles per shot.

Where the Find the Combat Shotgun in DOOM: The Dark Ages

The Combat Shotgun is the Slayer's default weapon and is available from the very beginning of the game.

Super Shotgun

All Super Shotgun Upgrades

  • Speed Loader (Tier 1) - The time between Super Shotgun shots is reduced.
  • Shatter (Tier 2) - The Super Shotgun deals increased damage to armor.
  • Eat This! (Tier 3) - The Super Shotgun fires an increased number of projectiles per shot.

Where the Find the Super Shotgun in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Players will unlock the Super Shotgun during Chapter 5 (The Holy City of Aratum).

Shredder

All Shredder Upgrades

  • Pincushion (Tier 1) - Dealing enough damage to a demon with the Shredder applies Pincushion. Hitting a demon with Shield Throw or parrying a Hell Surge attack detonates Pincushion, causing damage in a wide area.
  • Ricochet (Tier 1) - Shredder projectiles that hit a demon affected by Shield Saw strike one additional demon.
  • No Frills (Tier 2) - The Shredder's rate of fire is increased.
  • Barbed (Tier 3) - Detonated and ricocheted Shredder projectiles deal more damage. Hitting a demon with Shield Charge now also detonates Pincushion, dealing damage in a wide area.

Where the Find the Shredder in DOOM: The Dark Ages

The Shredder can be found near the end of Chapter 1 (Village of Khalim).

Impaler

All Impaler Upgrades

  • Stalwart (Tier 1) - Hitting a demon with Shield Throw, Shield Charge, or parrying a Hell Surge attack drops Impaler ammo.
  • Salvage (Tier 2) - Picking up Impaler ammo empowers your next shot.
  • Chronospike (Tier 2) - Holding R2/RT slows down time. Impaler projectiles fired during slow time deal more damage.
  • Lobotomy (Tier 3) - Headshots with the Impaler refill a portion of your next melee charge.

Where to Find the Impaler in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Players will gain access to the Impaler during the second half of Chapter 4 (Sentinel Barracks).

Accelerator

All Accelerator Upgrades

  • Feedback (Tier 1) - Shooting a demon with the Accelerator builds Charge. The Accelerator's damage is increased at maximum Charge.
  • Stabilizer (Tier 2) - The Accelerator's spread is reduced at maximum Charge.
  • Modulator (Tier 2) - The Accelerator's rate of fire is increased at maximum charge.
  • Heatblast (Tier 3) - Releasing the trigger at Maximum Charge fires a damaging Heatblast that consumes all remaining Charge. Demons killed by Heatblast drop Accelerator ammo.
  • Mega Cell (Tier 3) - The time it takes for the Accelerator to lose Charge is increased.
  • Overload (Tier 4) - Shooting a demon at maximum Charge will Supercharge the Accelerator. Supercharge further increases damage dealt by the Accelerator and its Charge-related effects.

Where to Find the Accelerator in DOOM: The Dark Ages

The Accelerator becomes available near the end of Chapter 2 (Hebeth).

Cycler

All Cycler Upgrades

  • Shock (Tier 1) - Dealing enough damage to a demon with the Cycler applies Shock. Shocked demons take increased damage from your attacks. Killing a Shocked demon with the Cycler arcs lightning to nearby demons.
  • Amplify (Tier 2) - The Cycler deals increased damage to Shocked demons.
  • Fulmination (Tier 3) - The duration of Shock applied by the Cycler is increased. Additionally, killing a Shocked demon with the Cycler generates more lightning arcs.
  • Overload (Tier 4) - Killing a Shocked demon with the Cycler builds Charge based on the size of the demon. The Cycler deals increased damage at maximum Charge.

Where to Find the Cycler in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Players will find the Cycler near the beginning of Chapter 5 (The Holy City of Aratum).

Pulverizer

All Pulverizer Upgrades

  • Runic Skull (Tier 1) - Killing a demon with the Pulverizer or Melee builds Charge based on the size of the demon. Your movement speed and the Pulverizer's rate of fire are increased at maximum Charge.
  • Runic Strike (Tier 2) - Melee strikes now build and maintain Charge.
  • Flay (Tier 3) - The Pulverizer fires an increased number of projectiles per shot over a wider area.

Where to Find the Pulverizer in DOOM: The Dark Ages

The Pulverizer can be found early on in Chapter 4 (Sentinel Barracks).

Ravager

All Ravager Upgrades

  • Vampirism (Tier 1) - While at maximum fire rate, demons damaged by the Ravager drop health pickups.
  • Ignition (Tier 2) - The Ravager takes less time to reach maximum fire rate and the movement penalty while firing is removed.
  • Slow Burn (Tier 2) - The Ravager's maximum rate of fire is increased but it takes longer to achieve. The movement penalty while firing is more significant.
  • Supplier (Tier 3) - Demons damaged by the Ravager drop Skullcrusher ammo.

Where to Find the Ravager in DOOM: The Dark Ages

The Ravager becomes available near the start of Chapter 12 (Sentinel Command Station).

Chainshot

All Chainshot Upgrades

  • Eldritch Blessing (Tier 1) - Parrying a Hell Surge attack instantly charges your next shot.
  • Gravitational Flux (Tier 2) - The Chainshot deals more damage to armor at maximum Charge.
  • Cosmic Breach (Tier 3) - Chainshot projectiles fired at maximum Charge explode when hitting a demon.

Where to Find the Chainshot in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Players get the Chainshot during the latter stages of Chapter 6 (Siege - Part 1).

Grenade Launcher

All Grenade Launcher Upgrades

  • Fragment (Tier 1) - Every third direct hit with the Grenade Launcher drops Cluster Grenades that deal area damage.
  • Rupture (Tier 2) - Direct hits with the Grenade Launcher drop Cluster Grenades when hitting a demon affected by the Shield Saw.
  • Cataclysm (Tier 3) - Every second direct hit with the Grenade Launcher drops cluster bombs.

Where to Find the Grenade Launcher in DOOM: The Dark Ages

The Rocket Launcher can be found in Chapter 8 (Abyssal Forest).

Rocket Launcher

All Rocket Launcher Upgrades

  • Cannibalism (Tier 1) - Parrying a Hell Surge attack temporarily causes self-damage to heal you.
  • Cooked (Tier 2) - Parrying a Hell Suge projectile empowers your next shot.
  • Blood Sacrifice (Tier 2) - Rocket Launcher projectiles deal increased splash damage at the cost of more self-damage.
  • Bloodlust (Tier 3) - Cannibalism lasts significantly longer.

Where to Find the Rocket Launcher in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Players will get their hands on the Rocket Launcher during Chapter 10 (The Forsaken Plains).

Ballistic Force Crossbow

All Ballistic Force Crossbow Upgrades

Unlike all of the other weapons in DOOM: The Dark Ages , players will not be able to upgrade the Ballistic Force Crossbow. They won't be able to select it using the weapon wheel either, with the BFC instead having its very own hotkey (Triangle on PlayStation or Y on Xbox).

Where to Find the Ballistic Force Crossbow in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Players will find the Ballistic Force Crossbow near the end of Chapter 14 (Spire of Nerathul).

Shield Saw

All Shield Saw Upgrades

  • Retaliation (Tier 1) - Parrying Hell Surge attacks will trigger a larger, more powerful shockwave that causes nearby demons to Heavy Falter.
  • Power Surge (Tier 2) - Energy Shields that are hit by a Shield Throw will cause your Shield to bounce to nearby enemies.
  • Extended Edge (Tier 3) - Shield Throw has an extended reach against fodder demons.
  • Steadfast (Tier 4) - The Shield will recover faster from taking damage, and also recover faster after breaking.
  • Harvester (Tier 5) - Killing multiple fodder demons with Shield Throw will empower your next Shield Charge, allowing it to deal increased damage to the primary target.
  • Blade Master (Tier 6) - The stun duration of the Shield Saw is increased.

Where to Find the Shield Saw in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Players will get the Shield Saw at the start of Chapter 2 (Hebeth).

Power Gauntlet

All Power Gauntlet Upgrades

  • Finisher (Tier 1) - Increase the damage of the final hit of your Power Gauntlet combo.
  • Duelist (Tier 2) - Parrying Hell Surge attacks will speed up your melee charge regeneration.
  • Jolt (Tier 3) - The first hit of your Power Gauntlet combo applies Shock. Shocked demons take increased damage from your attacks.
  • Encore (Tier 4) - Your Power Gauntlet gains a 4th hit. This additional swing is only accessible when acquiring a melee charge from a parried attack.

Where to Find the Power Gauntlet in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Players will get the Power Gauntlet during the first half of Chapter 1 (Village of Khalim).

Flail

All Flail Upgrades

  • Conditioning (Tier 1) - Reduce the recovery time of a flail charge by five seconds.
  • Ignite (Tier 2) - Demons hit by the Flail are scorched and drop armor.
  • Resonant (Tier 3) - Flail strikes deal additional damage to metal shields and armor. These strikes will also generate armor shards.
  • Engulf (Tier 4) - Every Flail strike also scorches nearby demons and causes them to drop armor.

Where to Find the Flail in DOOM: The Dark Ages

The Flail can be found early on in Chapter 6 (Siege - Part 1).

Dreadmace

All Dreadmace Upgrades

  • Reaper (Tier 1) - Demons killed with the Dreadmace drop additional health.
  • Obliterator (Tier 2) - Dreadmace strikes increase damage to nearby demons.
  • Riposte (Tier 3) - Successfully parrying a Hell Surge attack when the Dreadmace is charged will grant you an additional Dreadmace attack. This bonus swing is available for a limited time. This effect cannot be triggered again for a short duration.

Where to Find the Dreadmace in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Players will get their hands on the Dreadmace during the opening stages of Chapter 15 (City of Ry'uul).

item.title: DOOM The Dark Ages Tips and Tricks
item.description:
Although the DOOM franchise has been around since the early nineties, it remains incredibly accessible to new players. This is particularly evident in DOOM: The Dark Ages , with the game's informative tutorials and excellent accessibility options helping to guide beginners through the fantastic main story.

However, there are one or two things that the game doesn't tell you, as well as a few simple methods that players can use to avoid missing out on secrets or bonus objectives. With these DOOM: The Dark Ages tips and tricks, beginners can ensure that they're getting the most out of their first playthrough.

1 Make the Most of Difficulty Modifiers

When players first boot up the game, they'll be able to choose from six difficulty settings. What some might not realize, though, is that it's possible to further refine the game's difficulty via the Settings menu. From widening the parry window to increasing or decreasing the amount of damage they do to or take from demons, players can tweak and tailor the experience so that it provides the perfect amount of challenge. If ever things start to feel too easy or too difficult, they can simply hop back into the Difficulty Modifiers menu and adjust as required.

2 Always Check the Map Before Progressing

Although it's possible to replay chapters at any point, completionists will probably want to find all of the secrets and collectibles during their first playthrough before moving on to a Pandemonium or Ultra-Nightmare run. With this in mind, it's a good idea to double-check the map before leaving an area to ensure that no gold or other items are left behind. Some secrets will only show up when players get close to them, but most will be there from the moment players arrive in a new area. They'll be able to tell when they're about to leave said area, thanks to the orange arrow icon that shows up at exits and points of no return.

3 Keep Track of Challenges

From Chapter 4 onward, all but one of the chapters in DOOM: The Dark Ages has two or three optional challenges for players to complete. If they head to the Challenges menu, players will be able to pin these to the left side of their screen so that they can keep track of them as they make their way through the chapter. For those who prefer a clean HUD, it's a good idea to make a note of the challenges at the start of each chapter. It's also worth re-checking the Challenges menu whenever a new weapon or rune is unlocked, as some challenges will only become active once their respective equipment has been obtained.

4 Be Mindful of Weapon Mastery

If players completely upgrade one of their weapons, they'll unlock a special challenge through which they can get their hands on a gold skin. These usually involve getting a certain number of kills with the weapon or using its upgrade skill a certain number of times. Those hoping to master every weapon in DOOM: The Dark Ages should keep track of their weapon challenges and ensure that they're making progress as they play. It is possible to farm mastery for every weapon in an hour or two after finishing the main story, although players can save themselves this time by doing it during their initial playthrough instead.

5 Follow the Trails of Gold

Those hoping to upgrade equipment in DOOM: The Dark Ages will need a healthy supply of gold. However, this rare commodity can sometimes serve a secondary purpose, with gold trails often guiding players towards collectibles and secret areas. Once they find a secret area, players should keep their thinking inside the box. If there's no door, they'll probably need to shield charge their way through a wall, or look for a ledge they can drop down to. If the door is locked and the means to unlock it isn't on the other side, they should be looking for a switch or lever, or a blue cog that they can throw their shield at.

6 Combat Tips for DOOM: The Dark Ages

  • Always try to parry green projectiles, as doing so will usually take out surrounding demons as well as the demon firing them. Later on, parrying projectiles will also activate your shield rune for a few additional kills.
  • Keep an eye on ammo and be sure not to waste it on fodder demons. If you constantly find yourself running out of ammo, consider switching Resource Values to high in the Difficulty Modifiers menu.
  • Try to take out the bigger demons first, particularly in more open areas where there are a lot of enemies around. If you let yourself get surrounded by several large demons, you're going to have a bad time.
  • Use shield charge to escape from dangerous situations. If you do find yourself getting overwhelmed, a well-placed shield charge can take you away to safety and give you a few moments to regroup.
  • Understand how all of the weapon upgrades work. Many of them have the potential to deal powerful secondary damage, but will need to be triggered in a very specific way before they can take effect.

item.title: How to Use the Dragon in DOOM The Dark Ages
item.description:
In the second part of the Ancient Gods DLC, DOOM Eternal has a cutscene in which the Slayer rides a dragon. DOOM: The Dark Ages takes things one step further, allowing players to mount and ride a dragon at various points throughout the story. Understandably, a lot of players are keen to learn how exactly this works.

Unfortunately, there are only a handful of dragon-riding sections in DOOM: The Dark Ages , although that doesn't make them any less fun. In fact, it could perhaps be argued that there's just the right amount of them, with the game's Atlan sections serving as a reminder of how there can sometimes be too much of a good thing.

When Do You Unlock the Dragon in DOOM: The Dark Ages?

The first chance that players get to ride the Slayer's dragon comes in Chapter 5 , the start of which serves as an extended tutorial, of sorts. Sadly, save for a few short cameo appearances here and there, this is one of only three chapters with prolonged dragon-riding sections, with the other two being chapters 13 and 14.

How to Control the Dragon in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Controlling the dragon is relatively straightforward and is explained quite thoroughly to players at the start of Chapter 5. For those who skipped over the tutorial, though, pressing R1/RB or L1/LB will cause the dragon to ascend or descend, respectively. R2/RT fires the Autocannon, and holding L2/LT triggers Assault Mode, which allows players to dodge by pressing the Circle/B button together with a directional input. Last but not least, L3/LS activates a speed boost, and R3/RS can be used to land, although only at designated landing sites. Players can refill the dragon's health by flying through blue rings and, on rare occasions, perform brutal finishers with R3/RS.

The only thing that players may need a bit of practice with is dodging enemy Hell Surge blasts, which, if done successfully, will empower their Autocannon so that it can destroy enemy shields. The key here is to focus on the shape of the blast and dodge accordingly. If the blast is horizontal, they should dodge up or down. If it's vertical, they'll need to dodge left or right. In some later DOOM: The Dark Ages chapters, blasts will sometimes extend outward in three directions, meaning there'll only be one direction that players can dodge without taking any damage.

item.title: The Best Guns in DOOM The Dark Ages (Weapon Tier List)
item.description:
Like so many of its predecessors before it, DOOM: The Dark Ages boasts an impressive selection of weapons. Some of them are returning fan favorites, but there are also some brand-new additions to the hugely influential FPS franchise.

Some of these weapons are much better than others, either due to their superior upgrades or their higher damage potential. This DOOM: The Dark Ages tier list will rank all of the game's projectile-based weapons based on a combination of these two factors.

S-Tier Weapons in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Ballistic Force Crossbow

The Ballistic Force Crossbow serves as DOOM: The Dark Ages ' BFG, albeit with a C instead of a G. It's capable of dealing huge AoE damage to take out large waves of enemies in an instant, making it the perfect weapon for anyone who finds themselves getting overwhelmed. The fact that it can be pulled out with just a single button press is a nice bonus. Unfortunately, ammo for the BFC is somewhat scarce, so players will need to think carefully about how and when to use it.

Ravager

The Ravager is easily the best gun in DOOM: The Dark Ages . With the Vampirism, Ignition, and Supplier upgrades equipped, players can dish out a ridiculous amount of damage while also refilling their health and ammunition. Sadly, it's one of the last weapons that they'll get their hands on, but once they do, they won't want to put it back down.

Shield Saw

Although primarily used for defense, the Shield Saw is also one of the best weapons in DOOM: The Dark Ages . The way it interacts with different enemy shield types when thrown adds an additional layer to the game's combat, as too does its ability to trigger secondary damage through the Pincushion, Ricochet, and Rupture weapon upgrades. Then there are the four shield runes, which allow players to go from defense to offence in the blink of an eye and help to cement the Shield Saw's spot in the S tier.

A-Tier Weapons in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Combat Shotgun

The Slayer's trusty Combat Shotgun is the first weapon that players have access to, yet once it's been fully upgraded, it can carry them well into the late game. By combining its Smelt and Flare-Up upgrades, players can ensure a healthy supply of armor pickups, allowing them to focus more of their attention on gunning than running. They will need to keep an eye on their ammo, though, which holds the gun back a little.

Impaler

The Impaler is one of those weapons that you're either going to love or hate, but when paired with a fully upgraded Flail, there can be no disputing the weapon's potential to cause chaos and carnage among the demon ranks. To get the most out of the Impaler (ie, a ton of ammo and armor pickups and additional melee attacks), players will need to be good at parrying and landing headshots, both of which become a whole lot easier with the weapon's Chronospike upgrade equipped.

Accelerator

The Accelerator is the better of the two plasma weapons thanks to its ability to generate its own ammo via the Heatblast upgrade. In crowded places, building up Charge and Supercharge can be an incredibly effective way to clear the area of demons. If and when players do run out of ammo, the resulting Heatblast should get them back up and running again soon enough.

B-Tier Weapons in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Shredder

On paper, both Pincushion and Ricochet are really cool upgrades. Unfortunately, however, the secondary damage they dish out isn't really worth the effort that it takes to trigger it. Some may find it to be a more fun option than the Impaler, but its damage potential is a lot lower, as too is its synergy with melee weapons.

Super Shotgun

The Super Shotgun makes you feel like just as much of a bad-ass as its combat counterpart, although its inability to generate any kind of pickups holds it back just a bit. It's not a bad gun by any means, but the Combat Shotgun is arguably a much better use of one's slugs.

Cycler

As far as secondary damage goes, Shock isn't too bad, nor is the Charge damage that the Cycler starts to deal after being fully upgraded. Damage-wise, the Cycler is definitely in the same ballpark as the Accelerator, although the fact that the latter can generate ammo pickups gives it a rather sharp edge.

Rocket Launcher

Like in previous DOOM games, the Rocket Launcher is a lot of fun to use. Cannibalism can be useful too, especially if players are using the weapon at close range and damaging themselves along with enemies. As one might expect, though, its relatively low ammo capacity makes the Rocket Launcher a special-occasions type of weapon, so players can't really rely on it too much. Granted, the same could be said of the BFC, although that's considerably more destructive than the Rocket Launcher.

C-Tier Weapons in DOOM: The Dark Ages

Grenade Launcher

To get the most out of the Grenade Launcher, players will need to land direct hits. This isn't particularly difficult to do (provided they're not too far away from their target), but then, if they're going to be using the weapon up close and personal and taking the time to aim it a bit more precisely, there are arguably much better options available. Once everything's been fully upgraded, there are four or five guns that can deal secondary AoE damage, so it's hard to imagine why anybody would want to settle for one that has such limited ammunition.

Pulverizer

Considering how good the Ravager is, the Pulverizer is a bit of a disappointment. It's unable to generate health, armor, or ammo, and although its high rate of fire and additional Charge damage can be useful in areas that are more densely populated with demons, the Ravager has it beat in just about every other area. Even in crowded spaces, players will likely find themselves burning through their Skullcrusher ammo a lot more quickly than they would have liked.

Chainshot

Perhaps there are some people out there who really like the Chainshot, but this writer isn't one of them. Sure, it can be useful against armored enemies, and the Eldritch Blessing upgrade can sometimes save a second or two for those hoping to trigger Gravitational Flux and Cosmic Breach damage. In all likelihood, though, most players will only ever use the Chainshot when all of their other guns have run out of ammo, which is somewhat ironic, really, given how prone it is to running out of ammo itself. This, when combined with its inability to generate more ammo, reaffirms the weapon's place in the C tier.
